questions.text: What is the upper limit of serum lithium above which a patient is said to have lithium toxicity?
questions.solution:
Lithium toxicity is considered when the blood concentration reaches 1.5 mEq/L (or more). 

Blood concentration of lithium in the treatment of mood disorders:

  • For treatment: 0.8 - 1.2 mEq/L
  • For prophylaxis: 0.5 - 0.8 mEq/L
  • Toxic levels: >/= 1.5 mEq/L

Manifestations of lithium toxicity:

  • Acute: Coarse tremors (most common), delirium, dementia, seizures, and increase in deep tendon reflexes
  • Chronic: Nephrotoxicity (lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus), hypothyroidism

The most effective means of treating lithium toxicity is dialysis. It is necessary for severe poisoning cases, where:

  • The patient is exhibiting symptoms of toxicity, or
  • Lithium concentration is 4 mEq/L or more. 

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: What is the incubation period of Salmonella typhi?
questions.solution:
The incubation period for Salmonella typhi is from 5 to 21 days.

The incubation period for Salmonella typhi typically averages 10–14 days, but can range from 5 to 21 days. The duration is likely dependant on the inoculum size and the host’s health and immune status.

Related Pearl: Diseases with usual incubation period

Disease Incubation period(days)
Dengue 5-8
Typhoid 10-14
Herpes simplex 5-8
Enterovirus disease 6-12
Poliomyelitis 5-20
Measles 9-12
Smallpox 12-14
Chickenpox 13-17
Mumps 16-20
Rubella 17-20
Mononucleosis 30-50
Hepatitis A 15-40
Hepatitis B & C 50-150

questions.text: A patient with acute ischemic stroke requires IV thrombolysis. His symptoms had begun at 6:30 PM and he was brought to the hospital by 7:00 PM. For this treatment to be beneficial for the patient, it should be administered within what time?
questions.solution:
IV thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke has been proven to be beneficial up to 4.5 hours after the onset of symptoms according to European Cooperative Acute Stroke Study (ECASS) III.

According to MoHFW (India), thrombolysis is to be carried out within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.

IV tPA should be administered to all eligible acute stroke patients within 3 hours of last known normal and to a more selective group of eligible acute stroke patients (based on ECASS III exclusion criteria) within 4.5 hours of last known normal.

questions.text: You notice the following finding on the transvaginal USG of a woman with amenorrhea. What is the earliest gestational age at which this can be detected?
questions.solution:
The given transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac. This can be identified by transvaginal USG at 5 weeks.

Cardiac activity in an embryo can be identified at 6 weeks.

The double decidual sac sign (DDSS) is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualised. It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac) and is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac. 

The double decidual sac sign differentiates normal pregnancy from the pseudo-gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy. Pseudosac is irregular, usually centrally located in the uterus, has no double decidua sign, and the sac remains empty. The illustration below shows the difference: 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female seeks your advice regarding emergency contraception, 4 days after unprotected intercourse. Which of the following will you recommend?
questions.solution:
Ulipristal should be recommended for the above patient. 

Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) that can be used as an emergency contraceptive. It should be administered within 5 days of unprotected intercourse. Levonorgestrel alone or combination of levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol regimens should be administered within 3 days (options a and b).

Another option to consider would be the copper IUD. It can be inserted within 5–7 days after an unprotected act after a negative pregnancy test.

questions.text: What is the average maternal requirement of iron during a singleton pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Maternal requirement of iron during a singleton gestation averages close to 1000 mg.

Iron requirement during pregnancy
Fetus and placenta 300 mg
Expansion of maternal hemoglobin mass 500 mg
Losses through normal excretion routes 200 mg
Total 1000 mg

The average iron stores in a non-pregnant female is around 300 mg. This falls short of the requirement of iron during pregnancy which is 1000 mg. Hence iron supplementation is necessary to prevent iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy. This also forms the basis for prophylactic iron supplementation during pregnancy.

Note: The Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (FOGSI) states that the iron requirement in pregnancy is 840 mg, as about 160 mg of iron is saved due to amenorrhea during pregnancy.

questions.text: In painful arc sign, the pain during abduction of shoulder occurs within _______
questions.solution:
Painful arc sign is seen in impingement syndrome which is due to repeated rubbing of the tendon (mainly supraspinatus) under coraco acromial arc.

Patient complaints of increased pain when the arm traverses an arc between 60 and 120 degrees when greater tuberosity negotiates the subacromial space.

Other tests include Neers impingement sign and Hawkins-Kennedy test.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with facial puffiness and frothy urine. Upon investigating, his urine was positive for proteins with no hematuria and no RBC casts. To conclude the diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome, the range of proteinuria is defined as >_____ mg/m2/hr and urine protein:creatinine ratio of >________.
questions.solution:
The currently accepted definitions of  “nephrotic range proteinuria” include:

  • Urine protein: creatinine ratio > 2
  • Urine protein > 40 mg/m2/hr
  • Urine protein 3+ or 4+ in dipstick test

As a consequence of the large urinary loss of protein, the patient develops hypoalbuminemia (< 2.5 g/dL) and gross edema.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female undergoes normal vaginal delivery and is discharged after an uneventful course. The number of ASHA visits that would be made to follow up on HBNC is _______
questions.solution:
6 ASHA home visits are to be made for a patient discharged to home post institutional vaginal delivery, as part of HBNC - Home Based Newborn Care initiative under NRHM. 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1)

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: What percentage of a patient's body surface area would need to show sloughing to make a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome?
questions.solution:
Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) involves less than 10% of body surface area (BSA).

Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

Based on the type of cutaneous lesion and extent of maximal epidermal detachment, the disease is classified as:

Disease  Epidermal detachment  Purpuric macules and atypical target lesions 
SJS <10% Present
Overlap SJS-TEN  10-30% Present
TEN with spots >30% Present 
TEN without spots  >30% (large sheets of epidermal loss) Absent 

The image below shows SJS in the early stages with mucosal involvement.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the ideal age for orchidopexy in this child?
questions.solution:
Orchidopexy is ideally performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.

Orchidopexy is done before 12 months of age to avoid the following complications:

  • Infertility
  • Malignancy (Risk may still exist post surgery)
  • Hernia
  • Testicular torsion
  • Infection

The management for undescended testes that are not palpable is:

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is upto 6 hours. TRALI is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs during or soon after blood transfusion. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: Community based collective antibiotic therapy for trachoma can be stopped when the prevalence of _________
questions.solution:
Community based collective antibiotic therapy for trachoma can be stopped when the prevalence of TF<5%.

The target set by WHO for trachoma is that the prevalence of TF in children aged 1 to 9 should be less than 5%, and the threshold of collective treatment for trachoma should be set at 10%. When the prevalence of TF is lower than 5%, community-based collective antibiotic therapy could be ceased. However, surgery for trachomatous trichiasis and improvement of hygiene should continue.

Elimination of trachoma as a public health problem is defined as:

  1. A prevalence of trachomatous trichiasis “unknown to the health system” of <0.2% in adults aged ≥15 years (approximately 1 case per 1000 total population)
  2. A prevalence of trachomatous inflammation—follicular in children aged 1–9 years of <5%, sustained for at least two years in the absence of ongoing antibiotic mass treatment, in each formerly endemic district
  3. The existence of a system able to identify and manage incident trachomatous trichiasis cases, using defined strategies, with evidence of appropriate financial resources to implement those strategies.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: A primigravida comes to the primary health center for a routine antenatal visit and enquires about consumption of iron tablets. Which of the following is recommended for pregnant women during the antenatal period based on Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme?

choices.text: 100 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 180 days
100 mg of elemental iron for 180 days

questions.solution:
According to Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given daily for a minimum of 180 days during pregnancy. It is to be started from the fourth month of pregnancy and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme (2018) is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Age group Dose Frequency Tablet Color
Children
6-59 months of age

 

1 mL iron and folic acid syrup

Each mL contains 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid

Bi-weekly

  Syrup
Children
5-9 years of age

 

1 Iron and folic acid tablet

45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated

 Weekly   Pink

School-going adolescent girls and Boys
10-19 years of age

Out-of-school adolescent girls
10-19 years of age

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid, 

Sugar-coated

 Weekly   Blue

Women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating)
20-49 years

(Under Mission Parivar Vikas)

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid, 

Sugar-coated 

 Weekly   Red
Pregnant Women and Lactating Mothers
of 0-6 months child

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy is continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days). It should also be continued for 180 days post-partum.

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red color

 Daily  Red 

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female, who has been a victim of a violent crime recently presents with complaints consistent with flashback phenomenon and multiple nightmares. To diagnose post-traumatic stress disorder, the symptoms should persist for more than _______
questions.solution:
In post traumatic stress disorder, the symptoms persist for more than one month. 

Duration Condition
2 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive

questions.text: Using impedance audiometry, stapedial reflexes are being assessed in a child with cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following cranial nerves is being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 7th and 8th cranial nerves are being tested in a child by assessing the stapedial reflexes. 

The afferent of stapedial reflex is the 8th cranial nerve and efferent is the 7th cranial nerve.

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient comes to you for advice. She is a known case of irritable bowel syndrome. She asks you when is the best time to take antispasmodics for her postprandial abdominal pain. What would you suggest?
questions.solution:
The best time to take antispasmodics for postprandial pain is 30 min before meals.

Antispasmodics such as dicyclomine inhibit the gastrocolic reflex and thus reduce pain due to intestinal spasms. It is best taken 30 min before meals so that the effective blood levels are achieved shortly before the anticipated onset of pain.

questions.text:
The PR intervals obtained from the ECG recording of 4 patients are given below. Which of the following patients has a normal PR interval?

Patient 1- 0.19s

Patient 2- 0.3s

Patient 3- 0.23s

Patient 4- 0.1s
questions.solution:
The normal duration of the PR interval is 0.12-0.2 seconds (3 to 5 small boxes).

PR interval is said to be prolonged if it is > 0.2 seconds and short if it is < 0.12 seconds.

It is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It represents the time from the start of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization.

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hematuria and melena for 10 days. Laboratory investigations reveal mild thrombocytopenia and normal coagulation tests. Peripheral smear is given below. Which organism is most frequently involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide.

This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk.

The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells seen in HUS.  

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS

Features

TTP

HUS

Causative agent

A deficiency of, or antibodies to the metalloprotease ADAMTS13

E. coli (O157: H7)

GI prodrome

Uncommon

Often

Age group affected

Adults

Children

Sex affected

Females

No sex predilection

Relapses

Common

Rare

Renal impairment

Usually mild

Often severe

Severe thrombocytopenia

Often

Rare

Pentad of TTP and triad of HUS

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic man develops a gradually increasing demand for exogenous subcutaneous insulin therapy for glycemic control. His current insulin requirement is 130 IU/day. Downregulation of which of the following is associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of insulin resistance, which is characterized by the downregulation of GLUT-4.

GLUT-4 is an insulin-dependent GLUT. Other GLUTs are not insulin sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane. 

An arbitrary but clinically useful benchmark considers patients insulin resistant if they require greater than 1 unit/kilogram/day of exogenous insulin to maintain glycemic control. Patients requiring greater than 200 units of exogenous insulin per day are considered severely insulin resistant. 

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of ethanol a man must have consumed for him to be at increased risk for alcoholic liver disease?
questions.solution:
The minimum amount of ethanol that leads to an increased risk of developing alcoholic liver disease is 28g/day. In women, the minimum is 14g/day.

The risk factors for alcoholic liver disease are:

  • Quantity of alcohol consumption - The risk of developing alcoholic liver disease increases when alcohol consumption is >14 drinks/ week in men and >7drinks/week in women. A standard drink contains 14g of ethanol which is present in -
    • 120 mL of wine
    • 350ml of beer
    • 45ml of spirits (gin, rum, whiskey, vodka, tequilla)
  • Gender - Women have increased susceptibility to alcoholic liver disease
  • Hepatitis C infection - Increases the severity and decreases survival in alcoholic liver disease
  • Genetics -  A variation in patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3) gene confers an increased risk of progressive liver disease

questions.text: A child knows about her full name, age and gender but unable to tell a story. What will be the child’s age if her development is normal?
questions.solution:
A child knows about her full name, age, and gender at 3 years.

A child can tell stories by the age of 4. Hence, the child’s age in the given context will be 3 years.

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: The half-life of Iodine-131 is ________
questions.solution:
The half-life of Iodine-131 is 8 days.

Iodine 131 is used for destruction of thyroid tissues due to the production of beta rays. Iodine 123 has only gamma activity and is used as a nuclear imaging tracer.

Half-lives of other radioactive iodine:

  • Iodine 123 has a half-life of 13 hours
  • Iodine 125 has a half-life of 60 days
  • Iodine 124 has a half-life of 4.18 days

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
questions.solution:
In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 2 weeks, and therefore, the infant must be screened in 2 weeks i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age, as per the guidelines for the management of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). 

ROP guidelines state that the first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks of postnatal age (after birth) or between 31–33 weeks of post-conceptional age (calculated as gestational age + postnatal age), whichever is later. Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with epistaxis. On examination, you notice multiple petechiae and ecchymoses. Investigations reveal a prolonged PT (Prothrombin Time), normal fibrinogen levels and platelet counts. A diagnosis of a Vitamin deficiency is made. Which of the following clotting factors is unlikely to be affected by this vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely to be suffering from Vitamin K deficiency, as indicated by the presence of his bleeding manifestations. Vitamin K–dependent coagulation factors do not include Factor 8.

  • Vitamin K is required in the post-translational modification of blood clotting factors such as prothrombin (factor II), factor VII, factor IX, factor X, protein C, and protein S.

questions.text: What is the root value of Cremasteric reflex?
questions.solution:
Cremasteric Reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. 

  • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh
Deep reflexes Superficial reflexes
Biceps - C5, C6 Corneal - CN V(A) - CN VII(E) - Pons
Brachioradialis - C5, C6 Conjunctival - CN V (A) - CN VII(E) - Pons
Triceps - C6, C7 Scapular - C5, T1
Finger flexion - C8 Abdominal - T7-T12
Knee jerk - L3, L4 Anal - S3, S4
Ankle - S1, S2  Cremastric - L1, L2
Jaw jerk - CN V (Pons)  Plantar - L5 S1

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with complaints of Palpitations on standing up from the bed. His resting heart rate when supine is 90 beats/min. On examination, you would consider a diagnosis of  Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) if you note an increase in heart rate to __________ on standing:
questions.solution: Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) is characterized by symptomatic orthostatic intolerance without Orthostatic Hypotension, accompanied by either an increase in heart rate to >120 beats/min or an increase of 30 beats/min on standing that subsides on sitting or lying down.

questions.text: In pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated by ____.
questions.solution:
The diaphragm is elevated by 4 cm in pregnancy.

The anatomical changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are:

  • Elevation of diaphragm by 4 cm
  • Transverse diameter of chest increases by 2 cm
  • Chest circumference increases by 5-7 cm
  • Subcostal angle increases from 68 degrees to 103 degrees

questions.text: Osteoclastoma occurs most commonly in which of the following age groups?
questions.solution: Giant Cell Tumor most commonly occurs in age between 20 and 40 years.

questions.text: What is the generation time of lepra bacilli?
questions.solution:
The generation time of lepra bacilli is 12-13 days.

Generation time, also known as doubling time, is the time it takes for the bacterial population to double. It can also be measured as the time between two cell divisions under optimum conditions. The generation time of different bacilli are given below: 

  • Lepra bacilli- 12-13 days average (may vary from 8-42 days)
  • Tubercle bacilli- 15-20 hours
  • Coliform bacilli- 20 minutes

questions.text: You would classify a baby as a very low birth weight baby if the weight of the baby is found to be less than _____ kg.
questions.solution:
A very low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1.5 Kg. They are often premature (<37 weeks of gestation).

A low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <2.5 Kg.

An extremely low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1 kg.

questions.text: A patient who sustained an RTA was brought to the ER in a semiconscious state. He makes incoherent sounds, withdraws from painful stimuli, and opens his eyes to painful stimuli. Calculate his GCS score.
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient is 8.

Withdraws from pain = 4

Incoherent sounds = 2

Opens eyes to painful stimuli = 2

Total GCS score = 4 + 2 + 2 = 8.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: You are conducting the routine newborn assessment of a 2.3 kg baby born 10 minutes back. You would classify the neonate as having cold stress if you notice the body temperature to be:
questions.solution:
A temperature of 36.0 to 36.4°C categorizes a neonate as having cold stress.

An infant’s normal body temperature is 36.5 to 37.5 °C. It is measured in the apex of the baby's axilla by holding the thermometer for at least 3 minutes.

Hypothermia is an axillary temperature of <36.5 °C.

  • Cold stress: 36.0 to 36.4 °C
  • Moderate hypothermia: 32 to 35.9 °C
  • Severe hypothermia: <32 °C

Hyperthermia is an axillary temperature of >37.5 °C.

questions.text: What is the length of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The length of the eustachian tube is 36 mm (Bony part: 12 mm and Cartilaginous part: 24 mm).

It is directed forward, downward, and medially with an angle of 45° to the horizontal axis.

Note: The eustachian tube in infants is 18 mm, i.e. about half the size of an adult eustachian tube.

Related Pearl: Measurements of EAC and ET

 

External Auditory Canal

Eustachian tube

Total length

24 mm

36 mm

Bony (close to the middle ear)

16 mm (2/3)

12 mm (1/3)

Cartilaginous

8 mm (1/3)

24 mm (2/3)

Isthmus (narrowest part)

In the bony part

At the junction

questions.text: The total amount of amoxicillin that has to be administered per day in a 14-day anti-H.pylori triple-drug regimen is _______
questions.solution:
In triple-drug regimen, amoxicillin is administered as 1000 mg (1g) twice daily. Therefore, the total dose of amoxicillin per day is 2000 mg.

Triple therapy regimen:

  • [PPI + Clarithromycin 500 mg + Amoxicillin 1g] * BD for 10-14 days 
  • Metronidazole 500 mg BD can be substituted for amoxicillin

Related Pearl: H. pylori eradication regimen

 

1st line

[OCA/OCM - 14 days]

2nd line

[TOMB - 14 days]

3rd line /Clarithromycin-resistant cases

[LOA - 10 days]

Sequential Regimen

[OA (5days) + OCT (5days)]

Omeprazole

 Tetracycline Levofloxacin Omeprazole
Clarithromycin Omeprazole Omeprazole Clarithromycin
Amoxicillin/ Metronidazole Amoxicillin Amoxicillin
Metronidazole Bismuth   Tinidazole

questions.text: Apixaban is a:
questions.solution:
Apixaban, a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used in the treatment of VTE (Venous Thrombo Embolism)/DVT and in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery.

Direct factor Xa inhibitors:

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:

  • Bivalirudin
  • Argatroban
  • Desirud

Oral direct thrombin inhibitor—Dabigatran is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available for clinical use.

The FDA recently approved the drug Apixaban for a new indication. The drug is now used to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix.

Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:

  • Human Papilloma virus (most important)
  • Sexual intercourse before 18 years
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Multiparity
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Smoking and drug abuse
  • Women with STD, HIV, HSV 
  • Immune suppression

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD alone, seeking treatment for a minor medical condition. A general physical examination can be performed with just the child’s consent, only if the child is older than ______.
questions.solution:
A general physical examination can be performed, exclusively by the child's consent, if that child is older than 12 years of age.

According to section 89 of the I.P.C, a child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for their benefit. In these cases, the consent of the parent or guardian should be taken. If they refuse, the doctor cannot treat the patient even to save the patient's life.

Additionally, a father giving consent for an operative procedure on the child in good faith and for the child's benefit, though the said procedure is risky, cannot be held responsible if the child dies.

questions.text: The following suture material gets absorbed in how many days?
questions.solution: The image shows a violet color braided multifilament suture material which is vicryl (polyglactin). It gets absorbed completely in 60-90 days.

questions.text: SGLT-2 Inhibitors shift the renal threshold for Glucose from _____mg/dl to ____mg/dl.
questions.solution:
SGLT-2 Inhibitors shift the renal threshold for Glucose from 180 mg/dl to 50 mg/dl.

These agents block glucose transport in the proximal tubule and lower blood glucose by promoting urinary loss. As Monotherapy, SGLT2 inhibitors can cause a reduction of A1c by 0.7–1.0%, weight loss of 2–4 kg, and decrease blood pressure by 2–4 mm Hg.

questions.text: In an intubated patient, after what duration of endotracheal intubation will you need to perform a tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Tracheostomy is performed in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks.

This is because if an orotracheal or nasotracheal tube is left in situ for more than 2-3 weeks, it results in subglottic stenosis.

Hence it is ideal to replace the endotracheal tube with a cuffed tracheostomy tube.

If on intubation, it is perceived that the patient may require intubation for a period longer than 2 weeks, then tracheostomy can be performed soon after intubation.

Tracheostomy has been found to reduce the incidence of pneumonia, the duration of mechanical ventilation, and the length of stay in hospitals for patients with major head injuries.

questions.text: Duration of action of Proparacaine:
questions.solution:
The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 10-20 minutes.
 
Proparacaine hydrochloride ophthalmic solution is used as a topical anesthetic agent.
 
Indications: For procedures which require corneal anesthesia of short duration such as: 
  • Tonometry
  • Gonioscopy
  • Removal of corneal foreign bodies
  • For short corneal and conjunctival procedures
 
Contraindication: Patients with known hypersensitivity

questions.text: A patient has rushed to your clinic after she spilled hot tea on her hand. What should be the ideal temperature of the water used to cool her injuries?
questions.solution:
In temperate climates, cooling should be at about 15 °C, and hypothermia must be avoided. Moreover, studies show that ice cold water increases tissue damage.

Water at 15 °C provides analgesia and delays the microvascular damage in burns.

It should occur for a minimum of 20 minutes and is effective up to 1 hour after the burn injury.

Particularly important in scalds.

questions.text: Percentage of malignant transformation of fibroid is _______
questions.solution:
Sarcomatous change in a myoma is extremely rare, and the incidence is not more than 0.5% of all myomas.

Intramural and submucous tumors have a higher potential for sarcomatous change than subserous tumors. It is rare for malignant change to develop in a woman under the age of 40.

It is more commonly seen in a postmenopausal woman when it is observed that the tumor grows suddenly, causing pain and postmenopausal bleeding.

To the naked eye, a sarcomatous myoma is a yellowish-grey in color and hemorrhagic, with a soft consistency.

Sarcomatous change in a uterine myoma. (The dark irregular areas in the substance of the myoma which lie in the middle of the specimen represent areas of sarcomatous change.) The air level is seen within the mass indicative of sarcomatous change.

questions.text: What is the normal value of y/x in the following representation?
questions.solution:
In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4. 

It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis:
 

Predominant Bronchitis

Predominant Emphysema

Age (year)

40-45

50-75

Dyspnea

Mild; late

Severe; early

Cough

Early; copious sputum

Late; scanty sputum

Infections

Common

Occasional

Respiratory insufficiency

Repeated

Terminal

Cor pulmonale

Common

Rare; terminal

Airway resistance

Increased

Normal or slightly increased

Elastic recoil

Normal

Low

Chest radiograph

Prominent vessels; large heart

Hyperinflation; small heart

Appearance

Blue bloater

Pink puffer

questions.text: An anxious 45-year-old woman presented with complaints of a lump over her left breast for 2 months. The patient underwent mammography, and the lump was categorized as BIRADS 4a. What is the likelihood of her lesion being malignant?
questions.solution:
There is a 2-10% likelihood for a lesion with BIRADS 4a to be malignant.

BIRADS Categories/Grades

Grades 1 and 2: 0% chance of being malignant.

Grade 3: >0% but ≤2% chance of being malignant

Grade 4:

  • 4a: >2 to ≤10% chance of being malignant
  • 4b: >10 to ≤50% chance of being malignant
  • 4c: >50 to <95% chance of being malignant

Grade 5: ≥95% chance of being malignant

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy  ≥95% Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient is being evaluated for possible gastric ulcer. While performing his Esophago-gastro-duodenoscopy, the resident can expect to see the left bronchus crossing the esophagus at ________
questions.solution:
The left bronchus crosses the esophagus at 28 cm from the upper incisor teeth.

Normally esophagus shows 4 constrictions at following levels measured from upper incisors:

  • Junction of esophagus with cricopharynx (15 cm from the incisor teeth).
  • Crossed by arch of aorta (23 cm from the incisor teeth).
  • Crossed by left bronchus (28 cm from the incisor teeth).
  • It pierces the diaphragm (40 cm from the incisor teeth).

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
In a pregnancy complicated with a history of neural tube defect, 4 mg/day of folic acid is recommended.

Supplementation with folic acid is standard practice before and during pregnancy to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects and for as long as a woman is breastfeeding. 

Option A: In a normal pregnancy, folic acid is given at a dose of 400-500 mcg/day.

Options B and C: In adults with conditions having a high cell turnover like hemolytic anemia, supplementation of folic acid at a dose of 1-2 mg/day is recommended.

In hyperhomocysteinemia, folic acid is given at a dose of 1 mg/day.

questions.text: The antibody associated with chronic hepatitis C is _________
questions.solution:
Anti-LKM1 is associated with chronic hepatitis C and autoimmune hepatitis II.



Related Pearl: Antibodies in Hepatitis

 

Antibodies Seen in

ANA, ASMA, pANCA, anti-SLA/LP, AMA

Autoimmune hepatitis Type 1
Anti-liver cytosol 1

Autoimmune hepatitis Type 2
Anti-LKM 1

Autoimmune hepatitis Type 2 

Chronic hepatitis C
Anti-LKM 2 Drug-induced hepatitis
Anti-LKM 3

Chronic hepatitis D
  • ANA: Anti-nuclear antibodies (most common antibody in autoimmune hepatitis)
  • LKM: Liver–kidney microsomes
  • SLA/LP: Soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas
  • ASMA: Anti-smooth muscle actin
  • pANCA: Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
  • AMA: Antimitochondrial antibodies

questions.text: What is the ideal ratio of compression to ventilation that you would use in the resuscitation of a newborn?
questions.solution:
The ratio of compressions to ventilation in the resuscitation of the newborn is 3:1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths in one minute).

A 3:1 compression-to-ventilation ratio is used for neonatal resuscitation where compromise of gas exchange is nearly always the primary cause of the cardiovascular collapse.

Chest compressions are indicated if the heart rate is below 60/min even after 30 seconds of positive pressure ventilation. Once the HR is 60/min or more, chest compressions should be discontinued.
